loans.name: Srean

texts.en:
Mrs. Srean P., 38, is a farmer as well as raising pigs and earns around $1 per day. She is married and the mother of three children. Her husband, Mr. Saro Saran, 42, works growing rice with his wife. They both live in Anlong Snok Village, Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. P. is requesting a loan of $150 to fix their pig pen and purchase pig feed with any remainder from the loan money. The loan will allow her to improve her pig-raising business and increase the family’s income. In the photo, beside Mrs. P. is her husband.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To fix pig pen and purchase pig feed

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary K. is married and has no child. She has received schooling through the primary level. Mary sells groceries like canned products, vegetable oil, rice, and others at Siwdo, which she has done since 1998. Her husband is a commercial driver. Mary uses her income to assist her husband in building their family house. Mary will use the loan to purchase more groceries for her shop. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to reinvest and also use part to buy building materials for their house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more groceries for her shop.

loans.name: Muna

texts.en: Muna K.C, 39 years old, lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu. She lives in a single family. Her husband, Bhadri Kumar K.C,  is 36 years old. Her daughter and two sons are studying in grade 7, 4 and 1 respectively. She and her husband work together in a vegetable shop which was opened two years ago. Her financial condition is weak so she seeks Rs 20000/- to buy green vegetables. She also wants to earn more to provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: To buy green vegetables

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Née le 03 Avril 1945 à Bégbé dans le Zio, Mme Abra A. est une veuve très dynamique avec trois (03) enfants à charge. Son activité principale est la préparation et la vente de denrées alimentaires dans son village. Pour faire face à la demande et à l’exigence de sa clientèle, elle sollicite un crédit pour aménager un bon cadre sous forme de restaurant et s’approvisionner en riz et mais. Ce financement lui permettra de rentabiliser son activité et de s’occuper de l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Born on April 3, 1945 in Bégbé (Zio Prefecture), Ms. Abra A. is a very dynamic widow with three children in her care. Her main work is making and selling food in her village. To address the demand and the expectations of her customers, she is requesting a loan for fitting up a nice place as a restaurant and to get supplies of rice and corn. This financing will enable her to be profitable and to take care of the education of her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up a restaurant and for supplies

loans.name: José Feliciano

texts.es: El señor José Feliciano L. tiene la edad de 27 años habita en la comunidad palo de leche ubicada en el municipio de Ticuantepe junto a su esposa eh hijos, la esposa de don José trabaja como domestica para ayudarle con los gastos de casa, este señor tiene siete años de trabajar como agricultor, pero le a costado mucho tener una buena producción ya que anteriormente no tenia el apoyo de ninguna institución para comprar los suficientes insumos. El sueño de don  José es llegar a ampliar sus cultivos para darle una mejor condición de vida a su familia esta muy contento ya que Afodenic le esta apoyando para sacar mejor producción y vender a buen precio.
texts.en:
Señor José Feliciano L. is 27-years-old and lives in the community of Palo de Leche, which is located in the area of Ticuantepe. He lives there with his wife and children. Don José's wife works as a maid to help him with their home's expenses. This gentleman has worked for 7 years as a farmer, but it has been very difficult for him to have a good yield since previously he didn't have the support of an institution to buy enough supplies. Don José's dream is to expand his crop to give his family better living conditions. He is very happy that Afodenic is supporting him to produce more and to sell his crops at a good price.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds to increase and fertilize his crops

loans.name: Victor

texts.es: Víctor tiene 22 años, es soltero, vive en la casa de sus padres, juntamente con sus hermanos menores. De padres agricultores, y por supuesto heredó el trabajo con mucha entrega y dedicación a la tierra, está sembrando papa en grandes cantidades en la chacra de sus padres, además que les ayuda a ellos. En este año ha sembrado 6 hectáreas de papa, está muy contento porque le favoreció el mercado en el precio de su producto, comenta que en estos tiempos es bueno ser agricultor, pero es mucha inversión, y es esa la dificultad, cuando le falta dinero para comprar insecticidas y fertilizantes para que pueda producir como requiere el mercado. Este es su 7mo préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, en todo este tiempo ha demostrado ser muy puntual en sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado va a comprar fertilizantes como el nitrato y potasio para que pueda abonar su chacra de papas, inclusive cree que la faltará algo de dinero para la compra de pesticidas.
texts.en:
Victor is 22 years old, single and lives at home with his parents, along with his younger brothers. Since his parents are farmers, he, of course, inherited a strong work ethic and dedication to the land. He is planting potato in great quantities on his parents' ranch, in addition to helping them. This year, he has planted six hectares of potato. He is happy because the market favors him with the price of his product. He comments that in these times, it is good to be a farmer. However, the investment is great and the difficulty is when he lacks money to buy insecticides and fertilizers so that he may produce as much as required for the market. This is his seventh loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. In all this time, he has demonstrated that he is very punctual with his repayments. With the money he is requesting, he is going to buy fertilizer such as nitrates and potasium so that he can fertilize his potato ranch.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers for his potato farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy wheat, barley and other grains

loans.name: Safiatou

texts.fr:
Mme Safiatou D. est une veuve âgée de 41 ans qui vit dans une famille polygame avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Wala-Wala de la ville  de koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Son enfance a été perturbée par des problèmes familiaux qui lui ont empêché  d’étudier. Pour parvenir à satisfaire ses besoins, elle n’a pas  pris du temps pour se lancer dans les activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente des poissons fumés qu’elle aprit au près de ses amies il y a 25 ans. Les poissons fumés sont les plus prisés au milieu Miniaka puisqu’ils sont moins cher(que la viande ou la volaille) et que la majorité de la population est pauvre. 
Afin d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, elle décida de  rejoindre 
 l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya 4 ans. Après  6 prêts en solidaire ( prêt de groupe ) tous remboursés sans difficulté, elle est à son 2ème prêt en individuel dont le prémier  à été perturbé par le décès de son  époux, mais tout de même remboursé entièrement.
Elle compte acheter, 10 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé( Région de Mopti ) auprès des  pêcheurs  Bozo  et  Somonô , et effectue sa vente au  marché poisson de koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes  au comptant et à credit.
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice de 90.000FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso et investir le reste dans  certaines charges de la  famille. Son ambition est de diversifier son activité après la mort de son  mari afin de pouvoir correctement prendre en charge les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Safiatou D. is a 41-year-old widow who lives in a polygamous family, together with her co-wife and their children, in the Wala-Wala neighborhood in Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Her childhood was affected by family problems, which prevented her from studying. To be able to provide for herself, she didn't take long to start money-making businesses, notably the sale of dried fish, that she learned from friends 25 years ago. Dried fish is the most sought-after in her community where most people are poor, since it's cheaper than meat or chicken. To increase her revenues, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. After six solidarity loans (group loan), all repaid without problems, she's now seeking her second individual loan. The first one was affected by her husband's death, but was fully repaid anyway. She intends to buy 10 baskets of dried fish in Korientzé (Mopti Region), from Bozo and Somonô fishermen. She sells it for cash or on credit at the fish market in Koutiala, to a clientele composed of women and men. She intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 90'000 (ca USD$ 180), to be used to repay the loan. The remainder will be invested into some family expenses. Her ambition is to diversify her business after her husband's death, to be able to correctly provide for her children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell dried fish

loans.name: Adiru

texts.en:
Adiru V. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Adiru is 20 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has two children, and her children go to school.  

With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a lorry for hire.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs (non-governmental organizations) as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy a lorry for hire

loans.name: Jaqueline Enma

texts.es:
Jaqueline se crió en el cultivo de alfalfa, como la chacra que ahora ella trabaja, que pertenecía a sus papas. Su esposo la ayuda en la siembra, pero, como el también trabaja de constructor, no siempre lo hace.
De igual manera Jaqueline conduce su negocio bastante bien, hasta logra vender el alfalfa al por mayor en Lima. Las ganancias las usa para cubrir los gastos del hogar y de la crianza de sus dos hijas de 12 y 5 años.
A sus 36 años recién empezó a recibir préstamos de EDAPROSPO, hace una semana fue su primer préstamo. Con esto capital extra espera un día poder abrir una tienda de abarrotes, que es un negocio más estable durante el año, a diferencia del cultivo que va por temporadas.
texts.en:
Jaqueline was raised growing alfalfa on her parents' small farm. Today, her husband helps her tend these same fields, but since he is also a construction worker, he is not always available. Regardless, Jaqueline manages her business well, and even sells her alfalfa wholesale in Lima. She uses her earnings to cover both her household expenses and the cost of raising her two children, ages 12 and 5. She is 36 years old and last week received her first loan from EDAPROSPO. With this additional capital investment she hopes to one day be able to open a small grocery store, a business that offers year-round stability, as opposed to farming which depends on the seasons.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in alfalfa seeds

loans.name: Lawal

texts.en: K. Lawal is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She is a seamstress and she sews lovely clothes for her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sew more clothes for her customers. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing firewood and condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Santos Graciela

texts.es:
La señora Santos Graciela tiene 54 años y pertenece al Banco Comunal Unión y esfuerzo, vive en el caserío Túpac Amaru del distrito de Carabamba provincia de Julcán departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió solo hasta tercer grado de primaria por su propio esfuerzo debido a que estudiaba en la nocturna para poder mantenerse con su propio trabajo. Se casó a los 20 años y tiene 4 hijos de los cuales solo uno depende económicamente de ella.
Graciela tiene una bodega en su caserío, pero no es su única actividad económica también confecciona tejidos y elabora quesos.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, lo invirtió en insumos para la elaboración de pan, ya que en ese tiempo se dedicaba a ello.
Con este crédito de 2500 que será cancelado en 4 cuotas, lo invertirá en la compra de cebada, animales e insumos para la preparación de alimentos para la bodega.
Santos sueña con salir de su tierra y comprar una casa en otro lugar.
texts.en:
Santos Graciela is 54 years old and belongs to the Unión y Esfuerzo (“Union and Effort”) cooperative bank. She lives in the town of Túpac Amaru, located in the Julcán province of La Libertad, Perú. She studied only until the third grade through her own effort, given she worked nights to be able to support herself through her work. She married at age 20, and has 4 children of whom only one still relies on her. Graciela has a general store in her town, but this is not her only economic means, as she also makes knitwear and cheeses. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she repaid in 4 installments, she invested in the purchase of bread-making ingredients, which is the activity she dedicated herself to at that time. With this loan of 2500 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will invest in the purchase of barley, animals, and supplies to make foods to carry in her store. Santos dreams of one day leaving her land and buying a house someplace else.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals and supplies to make foods.

loans.name: Vinaca

texts.es:
La señora Vinaca. Pertenece al banco comunal “Rio Desaguadero” del distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno; de 60 años  de edad, es viuda y tiene 02 hijos, no tiene estudios; vive en la Comunidad e Lupaza sector Patáni. 
Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 8 años tiene su negocio de compra y venta de ganado menor, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00  nuevos  soles, que invirtió como capital adicional para su negocio. 
Debido a la demanda de sus clientes, actualmente ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, para poder invertir en la compra de mas cabezas de ganado, para incrementar sus ganancias y ayudar a su familia. 
A la Señora Vinaca le gusta mucho los ahorros y las reuniones  en las cuales nos cuenta que se distrae mucho con sus compañeras de grupo.
texts.en:
Vinaca belongs to the communal bank “Rio Desaguadero” of the district of Desaguadero, Chucuito Province, in the Department of Puno. Vinaca is 60 years old, a widow, and has 2 children; she never attended school. Vinaca lives in the Lupaza Community in the Patán Sector. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos program for the past 8 years and has a business in the purchase and sale of small cattle. Her first loan was of 300 PEN, which she invested and used as additional capital for her business. Due to the demand of her clients, she currently is requesting a loan of 3,000 PEN to be able to invest in the purchase of more head of cattle to increase her earnings and help her family. Vinaca enjoys saving, and the communal bank reunions where she tells us she is always entertained with her friends in the group.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more head of cattle.

loans.name: Najma Muhammad Hussain Khan Group

texts.en:
Seema baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Reshma baji wants a loan to buy material (leather and nails) for her shoe-making and selling business.

Irshad baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Saima Nazir baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business.

Najma baji is the wife of M. H. K. who has been a citizen of a mid-size city named Riwind, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband runs a dairy business. He gets milk from his buffalo and sells its milk to the milk shops and in the community.

Najma baji operates a business sewing clothes to save money for a rainy day. She is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies also. Her members are very happy to have her as a leader. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to increase the profit of her husband’s dairy business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for their dairy business

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama F., age 37, is divorced and has six kids. She sells biscuits and toffees on a wholesale basis--a trade she’s been doing for the past five years. Ama says combining motherhood and business is very challenging; however, the two must be attended to simultaneously. Currently, four of her children are in school and two are working. Ama is able to support her household well through her business. She needs a loan to purchase more stock to scale up sales. She hopes this loan will enable her to double her savings to provide quality education for the kids.

loans.use: To buy biscuits and toffees

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru: Ниезматова Фарида проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 30 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Фарида более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Оа имеет торговую точку, где в основном торгует хозяйственными товарами. Муж работает продавцом. Кредит, просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
30-year-old Farida N. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is married with three children. For more than five years, Farida has been engaged in trade. She has a salesbooth where on the whole she sells household products. Her husband works as a salesclerk. She is requesting a loan in order to expand her inventory.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding her inventory

loans.name: Yasohara Yesenia

texts.es: La señora Yasohara Yesenia C. A. , tiene la edad de 31 años habita en el Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla , junto a su esposo , él cual trabaja y le apoya con los gastos del hogar , ello tienen una hija de siete años , estudiante de primaria , los planes hacia su familia es mejora las condiciones de vida , doña Yasohara desde hace un año trabaja como domestica en una casa privada , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es que su sueldo no le ajusta para comprar de una sola vez el material que necesita para terminar de construir su vivienda . Los planes hacia un futuro es poder terminar de construir su casa. Con el préstamo va a comprar materiales de construcción para comenzar a construir ya que tiene una parte comprada y así lograr una vivienda digna para su familia.
texts.en:
Yasohara Yesenia C. A., 31, lives in the Juan Ramón Padilla neighborhood with her husband. He works and helps her with the household expenses. They have a seven year old daughter who goes to elementary school. The family plan is to improve their living conditions. Yasohara has worked as a housekeeper in a private home for one year. The biggest difficulty she faces is that her salary does not allow her to buy all at one time the material needed to finish building her house. Her future plan is to be able to finish building her house. With the loan she will buy construction materials to start building. She has already purchased one part. This way she will have a decent house for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction material to start building her house

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa es socia del Banco Comunal Amaquella que significa No seas Flojo en quechua.
Teresa es casada, tiene 44 años y 3 hijos, Teresa tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, frutas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. sus hijas, además tiene un locutorio que esta atendido por un personal.
Teresa necesita un préstamo D. 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. arroz, leche y azúcar.
Los sueños D. Teresa son tener una farmacia y mejorar sus negocios.
texts.en:
Teresa is a member of Banco Comunal Amaquella, which means “ Don’t be Lazy “, in the indigenous quechua language. She is married and is 44 years old, with three children. Teresa has a store in her house from where she sells staple groceries and fruit. She does this with the help of her daughters. She also has a call center which is handled by an employee. Teresa needs a loan of 1,200 soles. This money will be invested in the purchase of rice, milk and sugar. Teresa’s dream is to also have a pharmacy and improve her businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Veronica Martino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, milk and sugar

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
S., age 22, is a young mother caring for one lovely baby. She married her husband in early 2007, and they live away from their parents' homes. S. raises some poultry to sell, while her young husband earns a living as a fisherman. In addition, S. and her husband also have a farming business. S. has known the basics of cultivating rice since she was single – a skill she learned from her grandparents.

It is the farming season and the time for S. to grow a rice crop, but she lacks some farm supplies. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to buy a water buffalo to plow her field, and for fertilizers and rice seed to grow.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo, fertilizers and rice seed

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en:
Guadalupe is a member of the We are Leaders village bank. 
She is 39 years-old, married, and has two children who are 14 and 6. They study at public school. 
Guadalupe is from La Libertad, northern Peru. She arrived in Lima and started to study sewing but she did not like it so she stopped. Her mother-in-law has a stand that sells groceries typical of the jungle and Guadalupe wanted to work with her. Some months passed and her mother-in-law gave her the stand. 12 years have passed since she works there. She is very grateful to her mother-in-law. 
She is grateful to FINCA for the loans because she is able to invest them, her sales have been better and her economic situation has improved a little.  
She needs a loan of 1200 soles to buy dried fish called Paiche, flour from bananas, yucca. Everything is brought from the jungle. 
Her dream is that she wants to sell hot-dogs in the evenings from her house.

loans.use: buy dried fish called Paiche, flour from bananas, yucca

loans.name: Las Luchadoras Group

texts.es: El grupo “Las Luchadoras” esta representados por la señora Zulema y conformada por 12 miembros que en su mayoría se dedican al comercio de diferentes productos como ser pan, comidas, abarrotes, repuestos y salteñas en la comunidad de satélite norte. Tienen gran demanda de sus productos en la zona por lo que la competencia no es muy usual. El destino del financiamiento será utilizado para mejorar los utensilios para la realización de sus panes, masitas, salteñas y para buscar maquinaria que ayude a mejorar la calidad de su producto así como su productibilidad; el resto de las socias destinara el crédito a la compra de mercadería para poder incrementar aun mas su ingresos para poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida. En cuanto a la experiencia crediticia los socios ya tienen experiencia en grupos comunales gracias a créditos similares en otras instituciones por lo que conocen la modalidad de trabajo y saben como administrar bien los fondos otorgados.
texts.en:
The Group “Las Luchadoras” (The Fighters) is led by Sra. Zulema and consists of 12 members. The majority are involved in various retail businesses selling products such as bread, food, groceries, spare parts, and empanadas in the community of Satélite Norte. There is great demand for their products, so competition in their area is a rare occurrence.

For some members, the loan will be used to improve their equipment for making bread, pastries, and empanadas. They intend to find machinery that will help them improve the quality of their product and increase their output. The other members will use their loans to purchase merchandise so that they can increase their sales, which help them improve the quality of life for their families.

The members have previous experience working in communal groups thanks to similar loans they have taken at other institutions. They know how the loans work and how to manage the funds that have been provided to them.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
Socorro T. is from the town of Caputol. She is 55 years old. Socorro is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Socorro owns & operates a "sari-sari" store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Socorro has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for this activities.


In 2003, Socorro joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Socorro has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Socorro is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Socorro from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC:


Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Damdinsuren

texts.en:
Damdinsuren B. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His two children, 14 and 10 years old, both attend a local secondary school while his wife stays at home. B. sells women’s handbags in the largest Ulaanbaatar market, Narantuul. He began his business in 2000 after working as a geologist for a period of time. He purchases bags from China. B.’s working capital is 2,000,000 tugrugs and he has a healthy business profit of between 20% and 30% of that each month. He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more handbags and increase his working capital. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more handbags and increase his working capital

loans.name: Sophai

texts.en:
Sophai N., 29, and her husband, Hun Hor, 33, live on an island in Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 2001 and have two young daughters. One is in school. 

Sophai has been a silk weaver for almost 12 years. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village who sells to customers in Phnom Penh.  Her husband is also a silk weaver.  He used to be a wooden house builder. 

Sophai is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials to continue her family's silk weaving business.

loans.use: Purchase silk for weaving.

loans.name: Magada

texts.es:
La señora Magda es socia del Banco Comunal “Dulce Amanecer” desde hace 6 años atrás del distrito  y provincia de Puno, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 29 años de edad, cuenta con estudios secundarios completos, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos.
Magda se dedica a la compra y venta de frutas y nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo incrementar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 600.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar frutas como: manzanas, plátanos, uvas,etc.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia y abrir una tienda. 
Lo que màs le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y los incentivos.
texts.en:
Magda has been a member of the "Dulce Amanecer" (Sweet Dawn) Village Bank, in the District and Province of Puno, Department of Puno, for the past six years. She's 29, a single mother of two children, and has a secondary school education. She earns her living buying and selling fruits, and tells us that she was able to use her first loan of 300 soles from the Manuela Ramos Movement to increase her capital. Magda is seeking a loan for 600 soles, which she plans to use to buy fruits, including apples, bananas, grapes, etc. Her dream for the future is to have her own house and open a store. What she likes about her Village Bank are the savings and incentives.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy apples, bananas, and grapes.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza L., 41 years old, is a rice farmer from Norala in South Cotabato. Her family relies very much on her farm. Whatever income she makes from growing rice, it is a big help for her family to be able to buy food, clothing and other basic needs. She started tilling the farm in 1987. She will not stop until she is able to make all her children graduate from school.

She would like to request for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies. In that way, she will be able to increase her harvest and income.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
La señora Juliana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Sarita Colonia”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 34 años y 02 hijos que aun dependen de ella.

Juliana, es una mujer trabajadora y luchadora, se siente capaz de seguir a delante y trabajar con muchas ganas y así hacer profesionales a sus hijos, esta muy contenta con el trabajo que realiza, ya que se dedica a la venta de frutas y se encuentra ubicada en el Mercado “Pomarosa”, nos cuenta que sus ventas le salen muy bien ya que es muy conocida por sus clientes.

Juliana, poco a poco fue ahorrando, de esta manera es que decidió implementar su propio negocio.
Actualmente continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con el tipo de actividad que realiza. En su negocio, sus clientes encuentra lo necesario para preparar sus ensaladas y jugos  es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con amabilidad y regalando siempre una sonrisa.

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, comprará sacos de naranjas, mandarinas, limones cidras, taperibas y frutas en diferentes variedades propias de la región y de otras partes del país, para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes y encuentren lo que necesiten. 

Juliana, expresa haber cumplido algunas de sus metas que tiene trazada en su vida. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por ayudarla a implementar su negocio y a desarrollarse mejor como Mujer y Empresaria.
texts.en:
Juliana belongs to the Sarita Colonia Communal Bank in the Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín department. She is 34, in a common law marriage, and has two dependent children. Juliana is a fighter and a hard-working woman. She feels capable of getting ahead and working with great desire to have her children become professionals. She is very happy with the work she does. She sells fruit in the Pomarosa Market. She tells us that her sales are going very well because she is well known by her customers. Juliana was saving, little by little, in order to set up her own business. She currently continues with the same business, and she is happy with this type of work. In her business her customers can find what they need to make salads and juices. She personally waits on them with kindness, and she always rewards them with a smile. She will use this loan for 1,500 PEN to buy sacks of oranges, tangerines, lemons, citrons, taperebás (a native fruit of the Amazon region), and other varieties of fruits from the region and different parts of the country so that she can provide better service to her customers and give them what they need. Juliana says that she has been able to complete some of the goals she set for herself. Thanks to the help of Manuela Ramos, she was able to start her business and develop personally as a woman and an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruit to stock her business

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 26-year-old single man living alone and has been working in construction for the past nine years. In 2002, he started to take his own projects and began his own career. Working on a freelance basis, he worked on houses in his village and its surroundings. Youssef is very glad because over the years, he has been able to have a mounting number of customers.

Today, Youssef is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy construction tools and supplies because his business is growing and he's planning to take on bigger projects.

loans.use: To buy construction tools and supplies

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita A. is a 47-year-old woman with the strong courage to get out from the ties of poverty. She is a mother to six children; four of them are of legal age and the other one is a minor.  She is married to Simeon A., a vendor.  Unfortunately, the salary of her husband is insufficient for their daily needs.


As a woman of big dreams, in 2008 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since receiving the loan, she started a primary business of selling dry goods, which has helped support the financial needs of the family.  Now on her fourth loan, she is requesting 20,000 PHP to continue her primary business (dry goods) and pay for inventory (including dresses, shorts, underwear, sando, t-shirts, polo shirts and blouses) for her secondary business.


She hopes that, with the moral and financial support of ASHI and KIVA, she can reach her ambition to expand both businesses, pay for the needs of her children's education, and step out of the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: To continue her primary business (dry goods) and pay for inventory for her secondary business of RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes).

loans.name: Suria

texts.en:
Suria P. is 32 and divorced with 3 children (ages 12 - 15).  She owns a business venture selling cooked foods.  Suria has 1 year of experience in this business.  Suria needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 200 tala or US $83 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Suria joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Suria's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Suria P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.4 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.3 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.3 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.4 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: To make a more comfortable settlement, Mrs. S., age 41, grows a variety of crops on her own farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. Also, she relies on the income from her husband, who works driving a trailer-motor taxi around the community. This humble couple has five children, who are going to school and dependent on them. Recently S.’s husband can’t generate much income because his taxi is often broken. To solve the problem, S. sought a loan for her husband to replace his broken taxi.

loans.use: To replace her husband's broken taxi

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en: Erlita D. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 53 years old. Erlita is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Erlita is starting a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Erlita is just starting this business. In 2010, Erlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Erlita from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her child. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Charlene

texts.en:
Charlene P., 33 years old,  is engaged in food processing, firewood and a farming business. She has multiple businesses because she also has multiple expenses like food, clothing and other basic needs. She dreams of having her children finish their studies so that when they are older, they will be able to find better employment. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to grow her harvest.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa, toutes  mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des  familles polygames à Bougoula  Ville, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce tels les légumes (choux, carottes, aubergine) à l’image de Koura O., les pagnes wax etc..
Koura O. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  20 paniers de légumes 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Médine à Sikasso et  dans les vergers des villages voisins. Les légumes sont revendus au grand marché  de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses familiales et les évènements sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women in the Soro Yiriwa group are all married and are on average 40 years old with four children. They live in polygamous families in Bougoula Ville, one of the boroughs in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their 6th collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs. All past loans have been repaid in full. This group of women is in the retail business. For some it is selling pagnes wax (variety of colourful West-African clothing fabric), for others it is selling vegetables (cabbages, carrots, eggplants) like Koura O.. Koura O. wants to use her loan to buy 20 baskets of vegetables. She gets her supplies from the main Médina market in Sikasso and from orchards in neighbouring villages. The vegetables are then resold at the main market in Sikasso and through home delivery, for cash, to both men and women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 17,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and social events, and the remainder reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn O. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 44 years old and single. To make a living, Arlyn provides internet services in the local community and he also sells snacks and candies. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately $220 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Arlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials that he needs to continue to provide his service. This will be his 4th loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
K. Shuhrat is 30 years old. He is married and has 5 children. Shuhrat is an experienced bread baker. He has been doing this business for more than 10 years. He bakes the national bread “lepeshka” at home. His wife helps him with his business. Having many customers, Shuhrat sells the majority of his products from home. However, he also runs a trading place in the central local market selling ”lepeshka”. 


Shuhrat is requesting $1000. He is planning to purchase flour wholesale. Shuhrat is grateful to everyone who is supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy flour wholesale for making "lepeshka"

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en: Kenneth operates a cafeteria where he employs two people.  As a business man, he joined a group called Ngegu Small Traders in Faulu, Kenya to access financial resources.  He is able to save his money with the group members on weekly basis.  He has been guaranteed a loan of 40,000 KES by the group members.  With the loan, he wants to buy ingredients for cooking.  He hopes to buy a piece of land and build rental houses in the future.  Kenneth is a married man with two children.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Luzel

texts.en:
Luzel M. is from the village of Canitoan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 35 and married and with two school-aged children. Luzel has a store selling used-clothing and shoe products. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luzel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Luzel is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Luzel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand hers business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Canito-an, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Naciones Unidas Group

texts.es:
La Asociación Comunal “Naciones Unidas” está conformada por diez personas, nueve mujeres y un varón. Este es su segundo ciclo, la señora Cristina P. V. es la presidenta para este ciclo.

“Naciones Unidas” es una asociación comunal que pertenece al Centro Focal de Alto Lima.  La señora Cristina  tiene como negocio la producción y venta de zapatos, desde hace varios años;  el taller está ubicado en su mismo domicilio.  Ella indica que trabaja en forma conjunta con su esposo y su cuñado.  

Para el primer crédito la asociación le aprobó de Bs. 2000.  Ahora el préstamo solicitado es por Bs.2000.- y será destinado a la compra de material para la elaboración de zapatos. 

Las  integrantes de la asociación comunal tienen diferentes tipos de negocios: venta de pescado frito, venta de aceite, venta de abarrotes, venta de comida, venta de verdura, venta de cerveza, producción de calzados, producción de mantas y venta de fruta.
texts.en:
The “Naciones Unidas” (Nations United) Communal Bank is comprised of ten people, nine women and one man. This is their second cycle. Cristina P. V. is the president for this cycle. Naciones Unidas is a communal bank, which belongs to the community center in Alto Lima. Cristina has had a business producing and selling shoes for several years. Her workshop is located in her house. She says that she works together with her husband and her brother-in-law. Her first loan with the association was for 2,000 BOB. Now she is requesting a loan for 2,000 BOB. She will use the loan to buy material to make shoes. The members of the communal bank have different types of businesses like selling fried food, selling oil, selling groceries, selling food, selling vegetables, and selling beer. Some members make shoes, make blankets, or sell fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material to make shoes

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
For the last 12 years, Andrew has been operating and managing his mixed farm in Kisii, a town in western Kenya. His farm produces maize, beans, bananas, sugarcane, and milk, which he sells to the local market. He mainly depends on the income from his farming activities to provide for the needs of his family.

Andrew is 40 years old. He is married with two children, ages 4 and 5. Both children attend school.

He has requested this loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes to earn enough profit to enable him to build permanent business premises. He also hopes to open a big retail shop specializing in farm produce at his location.

He appreciates how far Juhudi Kilimo has brought him, and he has hopes that he will grow.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina M. is from the village of Sitio Tipan, Montol, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old. Marcelina is married and has 1 school-aged child and 2 adult children. She owns & operates a general retail store where she sells a variety of goods. She has been engaged in her business for more than 4 years and earns approximately 1,000 a month.

In 2010, Marcelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to provide additional capital for her business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marcelina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family members.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Annah Fe

texts.en:
Annah Fe L. is 24 years old, married and has three small children. She is from the village of Kanitoan in Initao municipality in the province of Misamis Oriental on the Mindanao islands. Annah Fe raises pigs to sell. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Annah Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Annah Fe is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Marthe

texts.en:
Marthe is 51 years old and is married with seven children who are between 5 and 10 years old. She is a self-employed businesswoman selling a variety of foodstuffs such as different kinds of flour, plus rice, beans, wheat, etc. She has been in this business for about two years and her business hours are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Marthe needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to satisfy the demands of her customers. In addition to that, she will start selling Irish potatoes as they are asked for by a large number of her customers.

If successful, Marthe really hopes that she will earn a lot of money which, in turn, will allow her to keep expanding her business, create some other sources of income, and continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs to sell such as different kinds of flour, rice, beans, wheat, etc., and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeun Y. (pictured), is 30 years old, and her husband, Mr. Sovathana Rin, is 29 years old. They have been married since 2006 and have a two year old daughter. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb. 

Mrs. Yoeun Y. sells groceries in her village. Her husband is a librarian at Technical school for Medical care in Phnom Penh. She wants to expand her business, so she is asking for her first loan of $200 to purchase additional grocery items for resale.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase of more timber for resale.

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
Batchuluun D. is 62 years old and lives with his wife in the Hovd province of Mongolia.  He and his wife live in their own house which was built from his business earnings. Batchuluun and his wife operate a grocery store in their yard. In 2006, he had built his own work place and opened his grocery shop in it. Since then, they have found success in a short period of time and have managed to increase their working capital.  

Over years of stable operation, he was able to build a house for his family. Batchuluun wants to continue to grow his business and increase his working capital. For the future, he plans to expand his grocery trading business. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan so that he can purchase a greater amount and variety of groceries for his food shop.

loans.use: To purchase a greater amount and variety of groceries.

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland S. is from the village of Olango. He is 24 years old. Roland is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $207 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Roland joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 24,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Roland is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 6th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 39 years old and married to Rosemary who sells cloth.They have been blessed with two children aged 15 and 10 years. He has been a carpenter for the last 10 years managing a profit of Ksh 20,000/= monthly. He is more likely to succeed because his wife contributes to meeting their expenses, hence paving the way for his growth.

The loan will be used to purchase timber. He plans to use the anticipated profits to purchase a grooving machine and grow his business further. This is his third loan with Kadet after successfully repaying the previous loans. He dreams of owning a workshop that will produce quality furniture.

loans.use: Timber

loans.name: Samuel Ovidio

texts.es:
Trabajar en la calle es un oficio que Samuel Ovidio O. conoce desde hace 19 años, puesto que su limitada educación formal y  la falta de oportunidades laborales, sumadas a la llegada de su primer hijo, lo obligaron a buscar opciones para el sustento de su familia. 

Fue entonces cuando Samuel empezó a vender periódicos en un conocido barrio de Medellín llamado Laureles, lugar donde actualmente continúa con su oficio inicial, al cual le sumó la venta de dulces, cigarrillos y llamadas a celular. 

Para Samuel tanto el sol como la lluvia son limitantes pues la calle es su sitio de trabajo, para ello espera obtener recursos con el fin de adquirir además de cigarrillos y confitería, espera comprar un parasol que le permita cubrirse de la lluvia y cubrir su mercancía, también desea adquirir un cajón en madera para ubicar mejor sus productos. 

Aunque Samuel ya es reconocido en el sector, su meta es crecer en variedad de productos para obtener mayores ingresos, pues espera poder cubrir la educación superior de sus 3 hijos.
texts.en:
Working on the street is a trade that Samuel Ovidio O. has known for 19 years.  Given his limited formal education, the lack of work opportunities, and the arrival of his first child; he was obligated to look for options to support his family.

That is when Samuel started to sell newspapers in a well-known neighborhood of Medellín called Laureles.  That is where he currently continues his initial trade.  He has added the sale of sweets, cigarettes, and cell phone calls.

The sun and the rain are limitations for Samuel.  The street is his work site.  That is why he hopes to get resources to get not just cigarettes and sweets.  He also hopes to buy an umbrella that will allow him and his merchandise to be covered from the rain.  He also wants to get a wooden box to better cover his products.

Even though Samuel is well-known in the area, his goal is to grow with a variety of products in order to get more income.  He hopes to be able to cover the cost of higher education for his three children.

loans.use: Umbrella, products, and a wooden box

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en:
Nemesia is a married woman who lives in Medellein, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fishing business. Her husband, Ramon, who is 58 years old, works as a fisherman and also helps his wife’s business. The couple has eight children between the ages of 14 and 31. 

Nemesia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nemesia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, thereby uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing 13,000 PHP to buy fishing gear and equipment for the fishing boat. Nemesia hopes to continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. She is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through its alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and fishing boat equipment

loans.name: El Carmen Group

texts.es:
Esta unidad D. desarrollo se llama El Carmen porque es el nombre que tiene su comunidad. Las UDEs son grupos D. mas D. 10 personas que tienen una cuenta en el banco y se reunen cada ocho o quince dias para realizar sus pagos. Tienen un representante y un comite que lo gobierna. Este grupo esta ubicado en L. comunidad del carmen que pertenece al municipio D. San Miguel Soyaltepec en el estado D. oaxaca. Este grupo esta conformado por diez personas que se conocen desD. hace muchos años por que son vecionos en L. comunidad.

El representante del grupo se llama Judith D. T., tiene 25 años D. edad, es soltera y actualmente estudia L. carrera D. derecho. ElL. desD. hace mas D. cinco años decidio iniciar con su propio negocio D. venta D. pollos azados y tacos porque elL. queria poder pagar sus estudios, elL. venD. desD. el corredor D. su casa, el miercoles y el domingo venD. pollos apartir D. las dos D. L. tarD. y los fines D. semana (jueves, viernes y sabado) venD. tacos por L. noche. Judith necesita este credito para invertirlo en L. compra D. pollos, variedad D. chiles, carbon, carne, especies, aceite, tortillas, tomates, cebolL., desechables, y refrescos para preparar su comida y posteriormente venderL., elL. espera que esta inversion le deje buenas ganancias para seguir invirtiendo y poder continuar con sus estudios.	
	
Norma R. G. es parte del grupo El Carmen, elL. tiene 37 años solo estudio primaria y esta casada con el señor JOse Antonio Ruiz con el cual tiene cuatro hijos  D. los cuales uno es hombre D. nombre David tiene 16 años y asiste a L. preparatoria y 3 mujeres D. nombres Jaquelin D. 13 años que estudia L. secundaria,  berenice D. 11 años que estudia L. primaria y las mas pequeña mia D. 5 años y asiste al prescolar D. L. comunidad. Doña norma desD. hace mas D. 2 años tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su hogar llamada Abarrotes Bere L. cual esta pintada D. un color anaranjado, elL. decidio iniciar con su propio negocio porque queria ayudar a a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y los estudios D. sus hijos, necesita este prestamo para invertirlo en L. compra D. arroz, maiz, frijol, aceite, jabon y queso para resurtir su tiendita, tambien nos dijo que esta aprendiendo reposteria porque en un futuro desea agrandar su negocio y vender tambien pasteles. Doña norma espera seguir invirtiendo sus ganancias en su negocio y L. educacion D. sus hijos ya que desea darles una mejor clidad D. vida.

los otros ocho integrantes son:

Lucia C. T. - taqueria 
Nora C. P. - antojitos mexicanos
Antonia T. D. L. C. - polleria
Margarito T. A. - cultivo D. maiz 
CiriL. C. C. - antojitos mexicanos
Blanca Rosa D. H. - polleria
Modesta O. R. - panaderia
Celsa M. R. - cosmeticos
texts.en:
This development unit is called El Carmen because that’s the name of their community.  Development Units are groups of more than 10 people who have an account in the bank and meet every week or two weeks to make their payments.  They have a representative and a governing committee.  This group is located in the El Carmen community which is part of the municipality of San Miguel Soyaltepec in the state of Oaxaca.  The group is maD. up of ten people who have known each other for many years because they are neighbors in the community.

The group representative is Judith D. T..  She is 25 years old, single and is studying Law.  She decided over five years ago to start her own roasted chicken and taco sales business because she wanted to pay for her studies.  She sells from her yard at home.  On Wednesdays and Sundays she sells chicken starting at two in the afternoon and on weekends (Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays) she sells tacos at night.  Judith needs this loan to buy chickens, a variety of chilies, charcoal, meat, spices, oil, tortillas, tomatoes, onions, disposables and beverages to prepare her food for subsequent sale.  She hopes this investment will produce good earnings to continue investing and be able to continue with her studies.

Norma R. G. is part of the El Carmen group.  She is 37 years old and only went to elementary school.  She’s married to José Antonio Ruiz with whom she has four children.  One is a boy, David.  He’s 16 years old and goes to high school.  The three girls are Jaquelin, 13, who is in middle school, Berenice, 11, who is in elementary school and the youngest, Mia, who is five and goes to the local preschool.

For the last two years Norma has had a grocery store in her home called Abarrotes Bere which is painted orange.  She decided to start her own business because she wanted to help her husband with household expenses and with the children’s educational costs.   She needs this loan to buy rice, corn, beans, oil, soap and cheese to stock her little store.  She also told us that she’s learning pastry making because in the future she’d like to expand her business and also sell cakes.  Norma hopes to continue to invest her profits in her business and in her children’s education since she’d like proviD. them with a better quality of life.

The other eight members are:

Lucia C. T. – taco stand
Nora C. P. – Mexican fast food
Antonia T. D. L. C. – chicken shop
Margarito T. A. – corn farmer 
CiriL. C. C. - Mexican fast food
Blanca Rosa D. H. - chicken shop 
Modesta O. R. – bakery
Celsa M. R. - cosmetics

loans.use: For fast food sales, tacos, chicken, bread, corn, groceries and cosmetics.

loans.name: Los Angeles Caidos Group

texts.es: En esta foto se muestra al grupo llamado LOS ANGELES CAIDOS, el cual esta ubicado en el estado D. Puebla, México. El grupo esta conformado por 9 miembros. La Señora Flora R. V. es una D. las integrantes D. 69 años y estudió hasta cuarto grado D. primaria, es casada, en total tiene 6 hijos, 3 hombres y 3 mujeres. Es dueña D. una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes, ella comenta que aunque es chica ha procurado mantenerla bien surtida para que sus clientes no se vayan, tiene varios años ya con este negocio, está contenta ya que sus clientes le responden con su preferencia, la señora Flora es muy amable y da buenos precios. También se dedica a vender comida a obreros que trabajan en la maquiladora que esta cerca D. su casa, dice que este negocio le ha dado buenos rendimientos. Hoy esta contenta y satisfecha agradece el buen servicio y los créditos otorgados pues le estan ayudando a incrementar su negocio, comenta que este prestamo lo destinara a la compra D. más mercancia y para surtir su tienda, y con las ganacias comprar platos y basos para sus comensales. Por otra parte tiene el firme propósito D. poder arreglar alguna D. sus cuartos D. su casa pues actualmente estan todos techados con lamina D. asbesto. Ella esta segura que con la ayuda del prestamo en un futuro lograra su meta.
texts.en: This picture shows the group called "Los Angeles Caidos," located in the state of Puebla, Mexico.  This group is comprised of 9 members.  Mrs. Flora R. V. is one of the members, she 69 years old and studied through the fourth graD..  She is married and has six children: 3 men and 3 woman.  She is the owner of a small grocery store and says that even though it's small she has been able to keep it well stocked so her customers don't go elsewhere.  She has had this business for several years and is happy that her customers prefer it.  Mrs. Flora is very nice and gives good prices.  She also sells food to workers who work in the maquiladora (factory) near her home.  She says this business has provided good returns.  Today, she is happy, satisfied, and grateful for the good service and loans authorized because they are helping her increase her business.  She says this loan is destined for the purchase of merchandise to stock her store. She will buy plates and bases for her guests with the earnings.  On the other hand, she plans to help fix up some of her rooms in her house since they are already doing roofs with laminated asbestos.  She is sure that with the help of the loan, she will achieve her goal in the future.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock her store.

loans.name: Gemmalyn

texts.en:
Gemmalyn is a married woman who lives in Danao City, Cebu.  She earns her living by operating an abaca weaving business.  Her husband Joselito, who is 27 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have four children who are 5 months to 7 years old. Gemmalyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gemmalyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 to buy materials and abaca to weave so that she can continue to save up for future improvements for her business. Gemmalyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.Kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase materials for abaca weaving

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a food stall where she sells vegetables/spices.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food stall selling vegetables and spices, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 11,500. Marlene is borrowing PHP 28,000 so that she could increase the volume of vegetable and spices that she sells in her food stall.  This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 28,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marlene aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and spices to sell

loans.name: Josefa Ortiz Tetepec Group

texts.es:
El grupo Josefa Ortiz Tetepec llamado así porque las personas que la integran son vecinas de la colonia Josefa Ortiz  y Tetepec porque así se llama su población, esta integrado por 10 personas muy trabajadoras que luchan DIA a di para tener una mejor vida. 
Carmelita Pérez Nicolás de 36 años de edad es la representante del grupo, es madre soltera, una mujer muy admirable que siempre a luchado y trabajado para sacar adelante a sus tres hijos, la hija mayor esta estudiando la universidad y los dos mas pequeños estudian la primaria. Carmelita tiene una tienda de Abarrotes y Perfumería, que se llama URI-MAURI llamado así porque sus dos pequeños hijos Uriel y Mauricio. Ella tiene esta tienda desde hace 19 años desde que nació su primera hija, inicio con este negocio debido a la necesidad que tenia para mantener a su pequeña. Ella solicito el préstamo para comprar mas productos  como: arroz, azúcar, café, jabón entre otros  ya que últimamente había tenido  ventas muy bajas y no le alcanzaba el dinero para surtir su tienda, de las ganancias que obtiene es para mantener a sus hijos.
Otra de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora Martha Norma Vázquez S. de 35 años de edad quien esta casada con el señor Antelmo Quiroz Quiroz quien es campesino, tiene 4 hijos 2 mujeres y 2 hombres de las respectivas edades: 20, 17, 12 y 11 años.
Martha se dedica  a la elaboración de pan, para que ella pueda vender sus productos  tiene que ir  a ofrecerlos de casa en casa, ha tenido buenas ventas y por lo tanto tiene buenas ganancias, ya que en la colonia por donde vive es la única que hace pan, además de sus panes son muy deliciosos y existe variedad en sus productos. Ella inicio este negocio debido a la necesidad que existía en su asa porque no alcanzaba el dinero que aportaba su esposo y como sus hijos estudian, necesitaba más dinero.
Ella comenta que al inicio solo elaboraba 50 panes  pero con el transcurso del tiempo ah ido incrementando sus ventas, es por ello que solicito el préstamo para comprar más insumos y hacer más panes.
Martha comenta que su meta es llegar a poner una panadería en su población y axial poder generar empleo a la gente de su comunidad.
Las personas que integran este grupo son las siguientes:
Claudina C. R.: De 27 años de edad se dedica a la compra de plásticos para la venta.
Amada Yudiht Hernández Díaz: De 40 años de edad se dedica a la compra de dulces para la venta.
Martha Norma Vázquez S.: De 35 años de edad se dedica a la compra de insumos para la elaboración de pan para la venta.
Juanita Nicolás S.: De 33 años de edad se dedica a la compra de abarrotes para la venta.
Cita T. S.: De 36 años de edad se dedica a la compra de calzado y ropa para la venta.
Faustina Nicolás Martínez: De 31 años de edad se dedica a la compra de insumos para la elaboración y venta de tamales.
Azucena M. E.: De 34 años de edad se dedica a la compra de medicamentos para la venta.
Carmelita Pérez Nicolás: De 36 años de edad se dedica a la compra de abarrotes para la venta.
Yolanda A. Hernández: De 21 años de edad se dedica a la compra de ropa para la venta.
Jerónimo V. C.: De 71 años de edad se dedica a la compra de ganado vacuno para la venta.
texts.en:
This group is called "Josefa Ortiz Tetepec" because the members are residents of the Josefa Ortiz and Tetepec neighborhoods.  The group has 10 hardworking members who struggle each day to have a better life.  

Carmelita Pérez Nicolás, 36, is the representative of the group.  She is a single mother who is admirable because she has worked hard and fought to provide for her 3 children.  Her oldest daughter is studying at the university and the two younger children are in elementary school.  Carmelita has a store where she sells groceries and perfumes which is called "URI-MAURI" because her two small children are named Uriel and Mauricio.  She has had this store for 19 years, ever since the birth of her oldest daughter.  She started the business because she needed to support her small daughter.  She is requesting a loan to buy products such as: rice, sugar, coffee, soap and other items because recently her sales have been very low and she does not have enough money to stock her store.  She uses the earnings from the store to support her children.  

Another member of the group is Martha Norma Vázquez S., 35, who is married to  Antelmo Quiroz Quiroz, a farmer. They have 4 children: 2 girls and 2 boys aged 20, 17, 12 and 11.  Martha has a business making bread, which she sells door-to-door.  She has had good sales and good earnings, since she has the only business in the neighborhood that sells bread.  In addition, her bread is very delicious and she offers variety in her products.  She started this business because her husband's income was not sufficient to cover the family's expenses, and because they needed more money to pay for their children's education.  She comments that at the start she only made 50 loaves of bread, but over time she has been increasing her sales.  For this reason she is requesting a loan so that she can buy more supplies and make more bread.  Martha says that her goal is to eventually have a bakery in her town, so that she could provide employment for some people in her community.

The members of the group are the following:
Claudina C. R., 27, who sells plastic products.
Amada Yudiht Hernández Díaz, 40, who sells sweets. 
Martha Norma Vázquez S., 35, who makes bread to sell. 
Juanita Nicolás S., 33, who has a grocery store.
