He is asking for $525.00 as additional capital to buy more cocoa to sell.

loans.use: To buy more cocoa to sell

loans.name: Mwansiti's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Mwansiti is 39 years old and is married with 4 children whose ages range from 9 to 20 years old. Mwansiti is a clothes seller. She started her business in 2006. Every day, she works from 9am to 10pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in clothing sales and soft drink sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Manikala Group

texts.en:
Yonbo is the group leader and a Kiva client who has completed her repayment. With her previous loan, Yonbo increased her income and was able to take care of her children. She also expanded her rice farm. Yonbo is a widow, but recently she also lost her daughter, leaving her with a day-old baby. At 47 years old, Yonbo now has the responsibility of taking care of her grandchild.

The group has 5 members, but the other 3 members went to purchase their business stock and were not available for the group photo. Like Yonbo, Saio KaM. sells palm oil, rice, soap, etc. Occasionally Yonbo and Saio purchase kenel nuts and produce palm oil. The 2 members would like to expand their businesses and are therefore requesting a loan of Le.2200000.

loans.use: To increase stock and generate more income

loans.name: Maria Jesus

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Jesús L. has a business raising chickens and pigs at her house.

She has had the business for thirteen years, and thanks to this has been able to get ahead with her five children. Her husband works in construction.

She tends to and feeds the chickens and pigs, which she buys when they are small. She then sells them to the local market. Thanks to her great care, she has customers who seek her out at home to purchase her animals of different sizes.

She has fought hard to advance with her family. Her oldest daughter, age thirteen, is in school continuing her studies which makes Maria very happy.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Jesús L. tiene un negocio de crianza de pollos y marranos en su casa. Tiene 13 años de haberse iniciado en este negocio, y gracias a el ha salido adelante con sus 5 hijos. Su esposo trabaja en la industria de la construcción. Ella cuida y alimenta a los pollos y marranos los cuales compra pequeños, y después los vende en su casa y el mercado local, gracias a sus buenos cuidados tiene clientes que la buscan en su casa para comprarle los animales de diferentes tamaños. Ella ha luchado mucho para salir adelante con su familia, su hija mayor de 13 años ya esta en el ciclo básico de educación, y eso la pone a ella muy contenta

loans.use: Purchase chicken and pigs to raise and sell.

loans.name: Martin

texts.es:
Martin started this business in order to have an income to allow him to support his wife and not have to do without necessities nor have economic difficulties. He was faced with the need of a way to generate income, because before he was working in the Armed Forces of Mexico (Navy,) and when he left he did not have work. So, together with his wife he started selling jewelry and it went very well for them, and because of this he now has another income through a Taxi. He started in December of 2001 selling jewelry with his wife, and thanks to this going so well they were able to acquire the Taxi 3 years ago. But now he is no longer buying and selling jewelry because his wife has started to work with a company full time and has no time for the jewelry. So therefore the only business that he’s working at now is the Taxi.

He needs a loan of US$500 that he will pay in 4 months to buy tires and shock absorbers as well as a tune-up for the engine, which will allow him to provide a better service for his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Martin inició el negocio para tener un ingreso que le permitiera sostener a su esposa y no tener que pasar necesidades ni apuros económicos, ante la necesidad de tener una actividad en la que percibiera un ingreso, ya que anteriormente había trabajado en la Armada de México (Marina) y cuando se retiro no tenía trabajo, fue por eso que junto con su esposa comenzó vendiendo joyería y les fue muy bien, es por eso que ahora cuento con otro ingreso extra a través del Taxi. Comenzó en Diciembre de 2001, vendiendo joyería con su esposa, y gracias a que les fue bien pudieron adquirir el Taxi hace 3 años, pero en la actualidad ha dejado la actividad de la compra-venta de joyería ya que su esposa entró a trabajar a una empresa de tiempo completo y ya no le queda tiempo para la joyería por lo que el único negocio al que se dedica es al Taxi

El necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar llantas y amortiguadores así como para la afinación del motor, lo cual le permitirá dar un mejor servicio a los usuarios del transporte.

loans.use: Taxi Maintenance

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Miss Patricia is 42 years old and she finished secondary education. She didn’t keep on studying because her family didn’t have the economic resources. Her Dad was a mechanic and her Mom was a housewife, and they had several children. The partner has 2 children who are in school. She lives in the District of Paiján in the Province of Ascope, at the Department of La Libertad. Patricia started with a small business, selling detergents, sodas, and sweets but in small quantities. She received a capital of $50 from an ONG from the US. This money was used to start the business. A friend encouraged her to be part of the Communal Bank “ HONESTY AND CONFIDENCE ”. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 4 years. With the first loan of $300, she bought toilet paper, rice, chicken, sweets, eggs, bread, etc. With this loan of $3,000, which she will repay over a period of 6 months, she plans to invest in buying a scaffold, a showcase and food for birds. The partner is the secretary at the Communal Bank where she belongs. Her functions are to keep a record of what happens during the meetings. Her wish is to expand her business in order to help her son with his superior studies.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Patricia, tiene 42 años, estudió secundaria completa, no siguió estudiando por la economía, sus padres no tenían solvencia económica, su Papá era mecánico y su Mamá era ama D. casa, tenían varios hijos. La socia tiene 02 hijos son estudiantes, vive en el Distrito D. Paiján en la Provincia D. Ascope en el Departamento D. La Libertad. La empresaria empezó con un pequeño negocio en el cual vendía detergentes, gaseosas, golosinas pero en pequeña cantidad, ella recibió un capital D. 50 dólares D. una ONG D. EEUU, este dinero estaba destinado para que inicien un negocio. Una amiga la animó a participar en el Banco Comunal “HONESTIDAD Y CONFIANZA”, tiene 04 años trabajando con Manuela Ramos y con el primer préstamo D. S/. 300.00 que recibió compró papel higiénico, arroz, pollo, golosinas, huevos, pan, etc. Con este préstamo D. S/. 3,000.00, que cancelará en 06 meses, tiene pensado invertir en la compra D. 01 andamio, 01 vitrina y comida para aves. La socia tiene el cargo D. secretaria en el Banco Comunal al que pertenece, cuya función es llenar en el acta, según lo que se acuerD. en reunión. Ella sueña con ampliar el negocio para ayudar a su hijo en los estudios superiors

loans.use: Buy a scaffold, a showcase and food for birds.

loans.name: Marieta's Tawakal Group

texts.en:
Marieta, 35, is married with two children ages 9 and 2. She has been a milk seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Marieta is now looking for a loan to buy more milk in order to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Fatma, who sells porridge and snacks.

loans.use: To buy more milk for her business.

loans.name: Mostina A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Mostina A. M. from Kyela, married with three children between the ages of 3 and 14. Mostina has been running a cereal crop shop since 2006, selling maize, rice, millet, beans, etc. Assisted by her husband, she works 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, earning about $175 each month from her business.

Mostina is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy more cereal crops for reselling. In the future, she plans to own her own store so that she can fetch a higher price for her commodities. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cereal crops for reselling.

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: El Sr. A. C. habita en la Cmca. La Palma, Tecolostote, junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa Maria Esquivel y 2 hijos en edad escolar cursando el 5to y 6to grado de primaria.  El mayor ayuda a su papá en las actividades productivas, la Señora Maria muy temprano prepara la alimentacion para su marido y sus hijos ya que despues se integra junto al marido a darle seguimiento al cultivo de arroz de 6 Mzs.  El Sr. A. es socio de la cooperativa agropecuaria donde a traves de una inversion de C$.l5,000.00 tiene la oportunidad de ser socio de 1 trillo paa arroz, o que le permitira contar con este equipo, instalaciones que le dejaran mejores ingresos para el sosten familiar y hacer realidad su sueño de ser socio de este trillo que le servira como una empresa productiva para comunidad y sus socios.
texts.en:
Mr. A. C. lives in the La Palma neighborhood in Tecolostote with his family which consists of his wife Maria Esquivel and their two children who are studying in the 5th and 6th grades of elementary school. The oldest helps his father with their farmwork, while Maria gets up very early to prepare meals for her husband and children before helping in farming the rice with her husband. Mr. A. is a member of the agricultural cooperative where he has the opportunity to invest $775 to become a partner in obtaining a rice threshing machine. Having access to the machine will help him to improve his income to support his family. Realizing his goal of becoming a partner in this machine will help him to feel like a successful businessman in his community and amongst his partners.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Contribute 30% to the construction of a rice threshing machine

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali, 52, lives in the town of Nabatieh in southern Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Ali has been a taxi driver for 22 years. He is requesting a loan of $1000US from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.

Ali’s wanted to be a government employee, but unfortunately he couldn’t, so that is why he decided to be a taxi driver. When he first started his business, he found difficulty in being accepted by other taxi drivers. Ali excels in his work because of his driving skills and his good relationships with his clients. His clients are his friends, neighbors, family and others.

loans.use: To do maintenance work on a taxi used for income

loans.name: Celedonio

texts.es:
El señor Celedonio Pérez esta agradecido por el gran apoyo que le brindaron en su anterior crédito.
Ahora tiene un negocio más, la venta de alimentos preparados, el cual lo trabajan su esposa y dos personas mas, los carritos de frutas siguen produciendo buenos rendimientos, en este nuevo negocio requiere de mayor mercancía y un vehiculo para poder entregar la comida a diferentes partes de la ciudad.
texts.en:
Mr. Celedonio P. is thankful for the great support given him with his previous loan. He now has an additional business, the sale of prepared meals, in which his wife and two other persons work. His fruit carts continue to produce well. His new business needs more merchandise and a vehicle to be able to deliver the meals to the different areas of the city.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and a vehicle.

loans.name: Yolanda Enma

texts.es:
Yolanda trabaja con los préstamos de EDAPROSPO desde hace cuatro años, aunque no continuamente ya que su negocio funciona por temporadas. Así  que ella solo recurre a los bancos comunales cuando necesita capital para su comercio. A veces pide un préstamo para cubrir algún pago, y no tener que gastar sus ahorros.

Desde hace más de quince años, Yolanda se dedica a la compra y venta por pedido de quesos y carne a restaurantes en la zona de Chosica. Cuando es temporada de trabajo ella se ocupa del negocio algunos días a la semana, el resto los dedica a  cuidar de su hogar y su extensa familia, ya que a sus cuarenta y un años Yolanda tiene que cuidar a sus cuatro hijos y las familias de ellos, que todavía viven en su casa. Yolanda puede permitirse esto gracias a sus ingresos y a los de su esposo, que es maestro de obras. 

Con sus ahorros, y unos préstamos más, le gustaría en un futuro buscar un puesto en Chosica para abrir una tienda de productos varios.
texts.en:
Yolanda has worked with EDAPROSPO for the past four years, although not continually since her business is seasonal. She only approaches the community banks when she needs capital for her business. Sometimes she asks for a loan in order to cover an expense, so she doesn’t have to spend her savings. For more than 15 years, Yolanda has worked buying and selling cheese and meat to restaurants in the Chosica area. During her working season, she works several days a week. The rest of her time is dedicated to caring for her home and her large family. At the age of 41, Yolanda has to care for her four children and their families, all of whom still live at home. Yolanda can allow this thanks to her income and the income of her husband, who is a construction foreman. With her savings, and a few more loans, she would like to find a place in Chosica to open a a store selling various products.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meats and cheese

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad, 28, lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ahmad has been working as a car painter since 2000. He is requesting a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase paint and tools for his work. This is his second loan request; he repaid his first loan on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Ahmad decided on doing this business because of his experience.

loans.use: To purchase paint and tools for his work

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena is an oil and snacks vendor in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma. She belongs to the Frelimo B group loan (Group code 2028).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food, oil, and other items for snack preparation. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home, get more food for her family, and pay school fees for her children.  

Philomena is 43 years old, married, and has five children: ages 23, 20, 17, 14, and 5. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more oil and other ingredients

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is 54 years old, and she is divorced and a mother of four children. She has been married for almost thirty years now. She has been supporting herself and her children too. Currently two of her children are in school, while the rest are fully independent. She has a mini shop where she sells items like bags of rice, sugar, flour etc. She also bakes bread to supply the area where she lives. Others also come to her house to buy them.

With the slow pace of the business, she has opened a grocery shop just in front of her house and sells items like milk, sugar, tinned tomatoes, flour etc; but, the unfortunate thing is that she has insufficient working capital to run the business. With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality and a large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yesu Abusua Kuo’ which means 'God’s family'. She also hopes to receive GH¢1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials, lace materials, slippers, sugar, flour and tinned tomatoes.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
“Nothing is impossible with God” says Angelita B., a resident of San Antonio Ilagan, Isabela. She is 46 years old and married to Frecisco B., a farmer. They have two children: Jemma, 27 years old, already married and Jenny, 18 years old, a high school graduate.  Angelita and her husband are trying to look for more opportunities to be able to send their youngest daughter to college.  

Angelita is engaged in the hog raising business.  To further improve it, she is borrowing a loan of PHP 5,000.  She plans to use the loan to purchase two piglets and feed.  This will be of great help to her family as an additional source of income. She is hoping that through their savings, her daughter can pursue her college education.  

Life is difficult but Angelita wanted to prove that no matter how hard life is, she will survive together with her family by patiently struggling out from poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Soimahon

texts.ru: Соимахон 40 лет, замужем. Имеет 3 детей. Несколько последних лет занимается продажей детской одежды на центральном рынке Исфары. Арендует часть магазина. Свой товар привозит из города Истаравшана с оптового рынка. С МикроИнвест сотрудничает 4 года и получаемые займы использует целенаправленно на развитие бизнеса. Сейчас она планирует прикупить ассортимент новых весенних товаров и поэтому подает заявку на займ.
texts.en:
Soimahon is 40 years old; she is married and has 3 children. She has been selling children’s clothing for the past several years at the Isfara market. She rents part of a store. Soimahon brings her products from the city of Istaravshan, from the wholesale market. She has been working with MicroInvest for 4 years and uses the loans with a focus on growing her business. Now she plans to purchase an assortment of new spring products and this is why she is applying for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grow product assortment

loans.name: Jan Mohammad Group

texts.en: Jan M. is the group leader of Jan M. group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses. They want to expand their businesses and make them larger. Jan M. and Shazada want to take a loan for their bakery business. They want to complete there stock and buy wood,wheat,and make there bakery larger to attract more customers and export more bread in to town and hotels . Shammail wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy a new machine for her business. Kamelah wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling of fuel so he can expand his business. With this loan, they can collectively expand their businesses and make a better future for themselves and for their families.

loans.use: To purchase stock for the business

loans.name: Bellie

texts.en:
Bellie A. is from the village of Dulong, Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Bellie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Bellie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling fish, shrimp and snack foods. She also cooks and sells snack foods like sweet potato and fried banana. Bellie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Bellie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bellie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Bellie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is married and has five children--two are currently in school and the others are independent. She has been selling lace materials, textiles, and clothing materials for five years. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. For lack of adequate working capital, she buys a few stocks of lace materials and then sells them through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. She takes stock from the central market of Kumasi. With the loan, she wants to purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is married. She has two grown children who live with her. She sells sports outfits and footwear in the central market of her home town of Melitopol. Nadezhda’s kiosk is located in a busy part of the market which helps her keep her business running. She has been in this trade for 10 years. Her business has grown up to 15,000 Grivnyas in merchandise. Her net profit amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas.

Nadezhda is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase assorted merchandise and generate additional income. She enjoys working with this type of inventory and believes it is a niche where she feels most comfortable. Nadezhda’s trade has benefited a lot from lending services. She has repaid all her previous loans without any problems. We believe her focused attitude and determination will help her repay the current loan on time as well.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Saturnino

texts.en:
Saturnino D., is the 52-year-old father of four children. His business is rice farming and he started tilling a 4-hectare (10-acre) farm when he married Amelita Dequino. The income that he gets from growing rice has gone far in supporting the daily needs of his family.

Saturnino is asking if he could obtain a loan from CEVI to support his business. He said that the loan will definitely go to purchasing five bags of complete fertilizer and three bags of potassium fertilizer.

Saturnino is actively participating in the CEVI micro-credit program. He likes CEVI because they are offering the lowest interest rates among micro-finance organizations in the Philippines.

loans.use: To purchase 5 bags of complete fertilizer and 3 bags of potassium fertilizer

loans.name: Irene's Group

texts.en:
L. Irene is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 30 years old and married with 2 children aged 9 and 7, both in primary school. She also helps to take care of her parents in the village who are sickly. She is very hard-working and has had a motor vehicle spare parts business in Kisekka market in Kampala for 7 years. She is able to make 200,000/= as weekly profits.

She started up her business in 2002 after being an employee earning a salary, but now she is the one who employs others. She is faced with a lot of competition, high rent costs, taxation, and high transport costs for bringing the spare parts to Kampala from Dubai.

Irene has a plan of starting her own reflector workshop so that she would be able to increase her income; and in future, she plans, together with her husband, to build commercial houses in their home area of Mukono. She needs a loan to be able to buy more spare parts that are currently missing in her shop. The profits will help in catering for her household including the children’s school fees and saving for future developments.

loans.use: Buying more spare parts for her business

loans.name: Agwu

texts.en: J. is 40 years old and married with 5 children. She sells groceries, drinks, and body creams. She lives in Benin City. She is hoping for a loan of N60000 to purchase more drinks, groceries, and body creams.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Lucenas

texts.en:
Lucenas B. is from the village of Nazareth, Buenavista, Pagadian City. She is 49 years old. Lucenas is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lucenas owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Lucenas has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately  PHP a month for these activities.

Lucenas joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucenas is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lucenas from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma, de 35 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos y por el momento vive en la casa de sus suegros junto a su esposo.
Durante todos los años que se ha dedicado a la agricultura sus plátanos y cítricos no han superando las ganancias que le brinda al café; por ello, para esta década alquiló chacras de tierras fértiles en zonas netamente cafetaleras. Norma se siente muy dichosa de vivir en la selva central peruana por la fertilidad de las tierras y mientras espera los dos o tres años para la cosecha del café se dedica a la siembra de plátanos y frutos cítricos, pues así mantiene estable la economía de su hogar. Por ello Norma y su esposo se sienten muy contentos de dedicarse a sus chacras y tiene el anhelo de obtener buenas ganancias que les permita adquirir sus propios  terrenos de cultivo, pues por el momento siembran en los de su suegro.

Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP y en el ciclo anterior demostró ser puntual en sus pagos. Asimismo está muy contenta de ser parte de su banco comunal. El dinero que ahora solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de fertilizantes químicos y más plantas cafetaleras.
texts.en:
Norma is 35 years old and the mother of 2 children. At the moment, she and her husband live in the house of her in-laws.

Throughout her life, Norma has been involved in growing bananas and citrus fruits. However, the income from these crops does not exceed the profits that can be made from coffee. For this reason, she decided to rent a field of rich farmland in an area known for its pristine coffee plantations. Norma feels very lucky to live in the central Peruvian jungle where the soil is fertile. While she waits 2 to 3 years for her coffee crop to mature, she continues to cultivate bananas and citrus fruits because it provides a stable income for her household. Norma and her husband are very happy with their plantings and look forward to generating good earnings so that they can buy their own farmland. They are currently using her father-in-law’s field.

This is Norma’s second loan with MFP. The payments from her previous loan were made on time. She is very happy to be part of her Communal Bank. The money she requested will be used to purchase chemical fertilizers and more coffee plants.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers & coffee plants

loans.name: Sasu

texts.en:
Sasu V. is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school. 

Sasu is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes and beans to sell. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes and beans to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and a plough for harvesting corn

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma has a rice-farming business on land that she owns. She is 39 years old but eager to till the land to make it useful and productive. Emma supports six children in her family. Her eldest is 24 years old. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to have financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos to buy materials for maintenance of her rice field.

loans.use: Farm materials

loans.name: Habil

texts.en:
Habil Q. is a 36-year-old trader who sells mobile phones in the city center of Lankaran. He has 8 years of experience in this field and, during these hard years, he built his own store. He has two sons, of whom is he very proud because they are studying in high school and are very smart guys. He believes that they could be scientists one day. 

Habil applied for a loan of 1600 AZN to a open new store in the other part of city.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for a second store

loans.name: Valida

texts.en:
Valida A. is 40 years old. She’s married and has three children. The difficult circumstances and hardships in her life made her recognize the value of work from a very young age. For about 14 years, she has been purchasing young cattle and calves at the local market, and then raising and selling them. 

Valida is a very hard-working woman. Her diligence is incredible. Valida wakes up early every morning to feed her cows and bulls so she can fatten them and sell them at the best price in the local market. Her husband actively helps her with operations. Thanks to this activity, she can pay for her children's education. Valida wants to keep educating them because she hopes that they’ll reach the goals that they have set for themselves. 

She is requesting a loan of 1600 AZN to buy four calves to expand her business. Let’s support this brave woman who has a lot of courage and strength to live.

loans.use: To purchase four calves

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie, 44, is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She tills a rice field as a source of living for her family. She’s the mother of four children. Her eldest is 16 years old.  She needs additional capital to finance her farm. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, and requested a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to purchase farm supplies and to improve her rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Kea's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Kea P. is 43 years old. She is the leader of a group bank loan, which consists of six people, located in Krang Pou village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Thol Paok, are farmers who own a two-hectare field used to cultivate rice. They do not have enough money to support the farm, therefore, Mrs. Kea P. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pay for hire someone to do the plowing. Mrs. Kea P. is the mother of four children who all are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to pay for hire plowing.

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
La sra. Angela vive en la zona de Pueblo Nuevo en el Plan 3000, ella tiene 5 hijos que asisten a primaria y secundaria, ella sola mantiene el hogar ya que es Madre soltera y tiene que trabajar duro para sacar a sus hijos adelante, ella se dedica a la elaboracion de bolsos, hamacas, cinturones, carteras, collares y aros que vende a las tiendas de artesanias, ademas de que tiene muchos pedidos en el extranjero como ser en españa, ella elabora todo lo que le solicitan, los fines de semana se va en busca de las semillas que utiliza en los collares asi como las plumas que necesite, además de eso es profesora de tejido y elaboración de artesanias, ella capacita a las mujeres de su comunidad en tejido, teñido y demas collares y aretes. Es una persona muy proactiva ademas de ser conocida en la zona, esta contenta porque sabe que con este prestamos podra comprar la maquina de costurar que necesita para hacer un mejor trabajo. El deseo de la Sra. Angela es la de ver a sus hijos profesionales y tambien tener su casa propia.

Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Angela lives in the Pueblo Nuevo (New Town) zone in Plan 3000. She has 5 children who attend primary and secondary school. She alone maintains the home since she is a single mother and has to work hard to advance her children. Angela makes bags, hammocks, belts, purses, necklaces and hoops which she sells to artisan stores. She also receives many orders from abroad, especially Spain. She makes all they solicit, then on weekends, she goes in search of the seeds used in the necklaces as well as the feathers she needs. In addition, she teaches weaving and how to make artisan goods. Angela teaches the women of her community to weave and die fabrics and make necklaces and ear rings. She is a very proactive person and is very well-known in the zone. She is very content because with this loan she can buy the stitching machine she needs to do better work. Mrs. Angela's desire is to see her children become professionals and also, to have a proper house.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING A STITCHING MACHINE FOR HER ARTISAN CREATIONS

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina S., 29, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Joseph, a computer shop owner, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own computer shop and Internet cafe for two years now.

Regina has been a regular member of Kiva field partner the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends CCT's weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.

Now she has applied for a 12,000 Philippine peso loan. She plans to use the money to buy more equipment to expand the offerings in her Internet cafe and computer shop.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can better provide for her children’s education, and hopes they will have a bright future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment for an Internet cafe and computer shop.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline O. is 45 years old, married, and has two children. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports the home.
Roseline sells jewelry, traditional beads, clothes, shoes and hats. She loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Roseline has been in this business for a long time and hopes that her business will grow bigger and stronger. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more jewelry, traditional beads, clothes and shoes to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes, traditional beads and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy ingredients for baking cakes and pastries

loans.name: Alhaji M.

texts.en: Alhaji C. is 56 years old and has a spacious and well-organized shop located along one of the main streets in Makeni.  Alhaji has been a trader for a couple of years now and traded in local foodstuffs originally until recently when he diverted into selling provisions.  He is married and has eight children, all in school. Being a family man, he is very much determined to succeed in business and as such, he is currently in search of a loan to stock his shop with various items, thereby expanding his business. If successful in acquiring a loan, he intends to educate his children and construct a house from the proceeds of his business.

loans.use: To buy provisions for his store.

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.es: Genoveva L. Vda. D. H. D. 58 años D. edad se dedica a la elaboración D. pan, negocio el cual se encuentra ubicado en el municipio D. Nueva San Salvador, ubicado en el departamento D. La Libertad, lugar en el cual vive junto a sus tres hijos, dos menores D. edad, los cuales estudian educación básica y la mayor que se dedica a estudiar en la universidad. Genova se ha ganado la vida D. esta manera durante 30 años, oficio el cual aprendió D. su madre, la cual también poseía una panadería, y a lo cual Genova se dedica desD. joven ya que ayudaba a su madre, en la actualidad este negocio le ha permitido sacar adelante a sus 3 hijos, los cuales han dependido por completo D. ella a lo largo D. todas sus vidas, ya que Genova es madre soltera. Ella es una mujer que cuenta con muy buenas referencias por parte D. sus vecinos, ya que es muy trabajadora y luchadora, así mismo una madre muy responsable, la cual su prioridad son sus hijos. Genova solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar harina llamada harina fuerte y también harina suave, las cuales le permiten elaborar diferentes tipos D. pan, D. esta manera ella podrá aumentar su producción y percibir mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Genoveva L. Vda. D. Hernandez, 58, operates a business making and selling bread, a business she operates in the town of Nueva San Salvador in La Libertad. She lives in the town with her three children, the two youngest of whom are in primary school and the oldest in college. Genova has maD. a living making and selling bread, a skill she learned from her mother, for 30 years. Her mother operated a bakery shop and Genova started helping her with the business when she was just a girl. Owning her own business has allowed her to help her 3 children get ahead in the world. Genova is a single mother and has been the sole provider of her children for all of their lives. She is well regarded among her neighbors because she works hard and strives to get ahead. She is also a devoted mother and her children are her first priority. Genova is applying for a loan so that she can buy flour, both so-called strong flour and mild flour, and, in turn, make different kinds of bread. She wants to increase her production and her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for bakery business.

location.town: Nueva San Salvador, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta C. is from the village of Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 42 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Vicenta runs a food stall, selling snacks such as banana cue (deep-fried banana covered with carmelized brown sugar) and pancit (noodles) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $120 a month from this activity.

In 2005, Vicenta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: José Ovidio

texts.es: José Ovidio C. de 40 años de edad, es un hombre muy responsable y trabajador el cual se esfuerza día con día por salir adelante y poder contar con una vida estable junto a su madre, la cual se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar. José reside en la cabecera departamental de Santa Ana, lugar en el cual también esta ubicado su negocio el cual es un taller de reparación de maquinas, en donde desde hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este tipo de oficio, lo que le ha permitido ser muy conocido por su excelente trabajo y servicio brindado. José solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar diferentes tipos de repuestos para las maquinas que repara, de esta forma el garantiza poder atender todo clases de problemas que alguna maquina pueda poseer y de este modo mejorar su servicio y contar con más trabajo. José es una persona muy responsable, el cual cuenta con muy buenas referencias personales tanto de sus vecinos como de amigos, ya que es alguien quien posee muchos deseos de seguir adelante y poder contar con un mejor futuro tanto para el como para su madre.
texts.en:
José Ovidio C., 40, is a responsible and hard-working man who works daily in order to get ahead in life and provide stability for himself and his mother, who does the household chores. José lives in Santa Ana department’s capital city which is where he also has his machine repair shop where he has been working for the last 10 years. He is very well known for his excellent work and service. José is asking for funding in order to have enough capital to buy the different kinds of replacement parts for the machines that he repairs so that he can be sure to be able to take care of whatever kind of problem a machine might have thereby improving the service he provides and have more work. José is a very responsible person who has good personal references both from his neighbors and from his friends because he’s someone who very much wants to get ahead in life and count on a better future for himself and for his mother.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy machine replacement parts.

loans.name: Groupe 2 De Bogoba Togo

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe 2 de l’association Bogoba de Togo sont des femmes mariées dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 41 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de Togo dans la commune rurale de Sakoïba dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le but d’avoir des intrants agricoles à leur disposition au début de la saison des pluies et de pouvoir utiliser des hommes (manœuvres) pour le labour et le sarclage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne.
Elles cultivent du mil, de l’arachide et du haricot. 
Madame Nana  Fané compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 sacs d’engrais, 100 kg de grains d’arachide, 30 kg de haricot de semence et recruter la main d’œuvre (hommes et femmes) pour les activités de labour et de sarclage. 
Elle se ravitaille en semences et en engrais à la foire de Ségou (au grand marché). 
Avec sa  parcelle de 3 hectares, elle espère produire 15 sacs d’arachide, 4 sacs de mil, 600 kg de haricot et des fanes de haricot destinées à faire des bottes pour le bétail. 
Les bottes de haricot sont stockées et vendues pendant la période de soudure. Une partie de la récolte est auto consommée tandis que l’autre moitié est destinée à la vente. 
Elle a comme objectif à l’instar des autres membres du groupe de faire l’élevage des petits ruminants et d’assurer l’autosuffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
The six members of the Group 2 of Bogoba Association of Togo are women married in polygamous families; on average, they are aged 41 and mothers of three children. All of them live in the village of Togo, in the rural community of Sakoïba in the region of Segou (4th administrative region of Mali). They got acquainted through links of kinship and marriage. In order to have agricultural inputs at their disposal at the beginning of the rain season and to be able to hire men (laborers) for plowing and weeding, they sought help from Soro Yiriwaso. They are currently into the 2nd cycle of a farming loan. They are growing millet, groundnuts and beans. Mrs. Nana Fané intends to use her loan to purchase 2 bags of fertilizer, 100 kg of groundnut seeds, 30 kg of bean seeds, and to hire manpower (men and women) for plowing and weeding. She purchases her seeds and fertilizer at the Ségou fair (large market). With her 3 acre parcel, she hopes to produce15 bags of groundnuts, 4 bags of millet, 600 kg of beans, as well as bean vines intended to make bales for the cattle. The bean bales are stored and sold during the period of shortage. One part of the crop is self consumed while the other half is intended for sale. Mrs. Nana Fané, like the other members of the group, aims to breed small ruminants and to ensure food self-sufficiency in the village.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers, seeds, and taking on workers for plowing and weeding.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella D. is currently in the business of selling tea ingredients such as coffee, tea leaves and Sudanese local ones (the roots of the Bohura tree). She is requesting a loan to stock beans and rice to sell.  Stella is 30 years old and married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a small restaurant and make tea to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern SuD.. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia J. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 29 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Aurelia owns a fishing business, operating a boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Aurelia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years. She dreams of having all her children finish college.

Aurelia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurelia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair the fishing boat and purchase additional fishing equipment. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Aurelia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair the fishing boat and purchase additional fishing equipment

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. is divorced and taking care of one child. She has not received any form of education.  Efua sells foodstuffs such as garden eggs (small eggplants), tomatoes, salted fish and the like at Takoradi. Efua uses her income in insuring the well-being of her family.

Efua will use the loan to purchase more foodstuffs for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save to acquire a shop she could display her goods in.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie Q. is from the town of Trento. She is 35 years old. Vergie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Vergie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Vergie has been engaged in farming for over 10 years. She also raises pigs for fattening and sale. 

Vergie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Vergie is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and livestock feed. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Vergie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and livestock feed

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
Romel P. is from the village of San Isidro. He is 33 years old. Romel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Romel owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice to sell. Romel has been engaged in his business for over 14 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per crop.

In 2010, Romel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romel is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Romel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mwashamba

texts.en:
Mwashamba is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school.  She is a food vendor and for the past six years has sold samosas to her neighbors and passersby. In her business, she faces a major challenge of theft.  She has a second source of income from real estate rental housing. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Mwashamba hopes to own a well-furnished house in the future.  She is working with Yehu to get a loan to renovate her house. The house she lives in has electricity and piped water. With the Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to renovate this house, purchase cement, sand and paintings.

loans.use: To renovate her house

loans.name: Percy

texts.en:
Percy A. is from the village of Canitoan, Lingatong, Baungon, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Percy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Percy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products, and also buying and selling charcoal in the local community. Percy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Percy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Percy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Percy is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be her seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to poor households in Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for five years. Her main products are eggs and milk, which she sells to the local market. She also earns income from her motorbike transport business. She is 22 years old and married with three children. 

Christine has requested this loan of 26,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this dairy cow will increase her milk production and she will be able to provide her family with enough milk for consumption and sale, creating more income. Her biggest challenge has been the high cost of artificial insemination services. In five years' time, she would like to acquire two more dairy cows and a chuff cutter.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria vive en la casa de sus padres cuyo domicilio esta ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, zona Brasil. Ella tiene un kiosco donde vende libros. Es su principal fuente de ingreso para su manutención. Ella tiene una hija, vive con sus padres. 
 
El préstamo lo destinara para la compra de cemento, ladrillos y arena. Esto le permitirá refaccionar su cocina y tener un mayor confort.
 
Es primer crédito con Impro.
texts.en: Maria and her daughter live with her parents in the Brasil area of El Alto. She has a kiosk where she sells books.  It is her main source of income.  She will use the loan to buy cement, bricks, and sand to refurbish the kitchen so that her family will have greater comfort.  This is her first loan with Impro.

loans.use: To buy cement, bricks, and sand to refurbish her kitchen.

loans.name: 02.10.1.3 Group

texts.en:
Tuyet N. T. (9) is a 37-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Tuyet is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 10.1.3 Nam Ngan (02.10.1.3).
Tuyet is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Tuyet owns and operates a food stall selling a variety of food products in the local community. Tuyet has been engaged in this business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.
In 2010, Tuyet joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women for 5,787,900 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. Tuyet plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About the other borrowers in the group
1. N. T. Phuong (10) is a 48-year-old female who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 2. N. T. Tham (11) is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall. 3. D. T. Phuong (12) is a 40-year-old female who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. 4. C. T. Nhan (13) is a 47-year-old female who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Tuyet N. T. (9) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Tuyet là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 10.1.3 Nam Ngan (02.10.1.3). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Tuyet thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 1 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Tuyet kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND. Vào 2010, Tuyet đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Tuyet đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.787.900 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. T. Phuong (10) là 48 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. N. T. Tham (11) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 3. D. T. Phuong (12) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 4. C. T. Nhan (13) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Tamemsu New Site Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Tamemsu New Site” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are small businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of SLL 600,000 for each person in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Mamah K.. Mamah was born in Port Loka town about fifty-two years ago. She is married and has four children. Her husband is an imam and her children are no longer attending schools. 

Mamah sells cooked rice, uncooked rice, and palm oil. She has been a businesswoman for nine years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy rice, palm oil, etc. at wholesale to add to her business. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy rice, palm-oil, etc. to sell

loans.name: Naranjitas Group

texts.es:
La Banca Comunal “Naranjitas” está iniciando su ciclo número dos en el Centro Focal de GERMAN BUSCH. Cuenta con nueve integrantes, ocho mujeres y un varón.  Don Salustio es el único varón de la B.C. Naranjitas.  La mesa directiva está compuesta por la presidenta, la señora Lidia, por la tesorera, la señora Angélica y como secretaria de actas María.  Los negocios de las señoras están relacionados con el comercio, producción  y servicio, como ser: venta de pan, comerciante de ropa, venta de sombreros, mantas, comerciante en vinagre, chapista, venta de juego de aretes, tejido de mantas, venta de tunta (papa deshidratada) 
La señora  Lidia presidenta de la BC “Naranjitas”, esta casada y tiene cuatro hijos.
Hace mas de diez años, unas amigas le enseñaron a vender “tunta” y viendo que era un negocio que le brindaba ganancias decidió mantenerlo, actualmente ella compra “tunta” de la ciudad de El Alto, de una zona comercial llamada La Ceja y lleva a vender a la ciudad de Oruro. 
La señora Lidia indica que utilizará su crédito para comprar tunta,  debido a que es un producto muy requerido, debido a que se trata de un ingrediente importante en los platos tradiciones de fiesta como la sajta de pollo.
Cuando le consultan sobre  qué es lo que más le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el crédito.
Las señoras de la Banca Comunal “Naranjitas” se encontraban entusiasmadas por que tenían planificado compartir un plato de comida, este día de reunión, se ubicaron en la foto siete socias y la señora que cocinó el  plato (señora de chompa anaranjada y chaleco a cuadros, en la fila de atrás, de pie).  (La foto del señor Salustio se encuentra en esquina superior derecha)
texts.en:
The “Naranjitas” community bank is starting its second loan cycle as part of the GERMAN BUSCH regional office.  The group has nine members: eight women and one man.  Salustio is the only man.  The group's board is made up of the president, Lidia; the treasurer, Angélica and the secretary, María.  The ladies' businesses are related to commerce, production and services.  They include: bread sales, clothes sales, hat sales, blanket sales, vinegar sales, panel beater, hoop game sales, blanket weaving and 'tunta' sales (tunta is dried potato).

Lídia is the president of the community bank.  She is married and has four children.

More than ten years ago, some friends taught Lídia to sell 'tunta' and, seeing that it was a business that made good profits, she decided to keep it going.  She currently buys 'tunta' in the city of El Alto, in a business area called 'La Ceja', and she takes it to the city of Oruro to sell.

Lídia says that she will use her loan to buy more 'tunta' since it is a product that is very much in demand as it is an important ingredient in traditional festive meals such as 'saita de pollo'.

When we asked her what she most likes about Pro Mujer, she replied that she likes the loans.

The ladies of the Naranjitas community bank are happy in this picture because they are planning to share a meal on the day of this meeting.  There are seven bank members in this photo and also the lady who cooked the meal (the lady in the orange sweater and checked waistcoat in the back row, standing up).  Salustio's photo appears in the upper right-hand corner.

loans.use: To buy 'tunta' (dried potato)

loans.name: Bun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people living in Krapeu Ha village in Kandal province. The group members selected Mrs. Bun V., a 39-year-old married woman, as group leader. Each member will use the loan to support her own purpose. 

Mrs. Bun V. earns her living selling different vegetables at the local market. Her husband, Mr. Oem Malis, 50 years old, works as a construction worker. With both their jobs, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to increase her income to improve the family’s living conditions, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to enlarge her business. This couple has a child who is a student in a local school.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to enlarge her business

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MUJERES EN ACCION”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Anta, perteneciente a la provincia de Anta y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Nancy; ella tiene 39 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de productos lácteos y también se dedica a la venta de ganado vacuno, ella vende productos lácteos como leche, queso y mantequilla y el ganado vacuno lo vende en las diferentes ferias que existe, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de productos lácteos y ganado vacuno. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar productos lácteos y alimento para el ganado vacuno. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This borrower belongs to the "Women in Action" communal bank. The bank is located in the district of Anta, which belongs to the province of Anta and the department of Cusco.

Her name is Nancy; she is 39 years old, with a live-in partner and 2 children. She divides her time between her daily activities and her business selling dairy products, and she also sells cattle. She sells dairy products such as milk, cheese and butter, and she sells her cattle at various markets existing in the area. She is requesting the loan to buy dairy products as well as feed for her cattle. 

The borrower is happy about the loan, and she is committed to making her payments on schedule.

loans.use: Buying dairy products and feed for her cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a musical instrument

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Sabina es socia del  Banco Comunal “María Asunción Galindo”, ubicado en el distrito D. Juli, provincia D. Chucuito – Juli, departamento D. Puno, tiene 65 años D. edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos.  Sabina no tiene estudios.
Es socia del Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace diez años, su préstamo inicial fue D. S/ 300.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que pudo utilizar en la compra D. redes para pescar. Sabina se dedica a la venta D. pescado como, pejerrey, carachi y mauri,  esta actividad la realiza en las diferentes ferias D. juli.  El que realiza la pesca es su esposo.
Con éste préstamo D. S/ 1000.00 nuevo soles, comprará redes y reemplazará las redes envejecidas para poder mejorar su pesca. En la fotografía se aprecia a la señora desenredando  una malla.
 La socia afirma que ya no tiene sueños por la edad avanzada en que se encuentra.
Lo que le gusta  del Banco Comunal es la facilidad del préstamo y las reuniones con las socias.
texts.en:
Sabina is a member of the communal bank, " Maria Asuncion Galindo";which is located in the district of Juli, a province of Chucuito-Juli, and in the Puno section. Sabina is 65 years old, married with 4 children, and has no formal education.

She has belong to the Manuela Ramos Movement for the last 10 years.  Her first loan was for 300 Nuevo Soles, a loan she was able to use to purchase fishing nets.  Sabina sells fish such as: silversiD., carachi, and marui which she sells at the various fairs in Juli.  Her husband is the one who actually does the fishing.
With this loan of 1000.00 Neuvo Soles, she will purchase nets to replace the old ones in order to improve her catch.  In the picture above, Sabina can be seen untangling a net.
Sabina affirms that at her age she no longer has any dreams.
What she likes about the communal bank is the ease of the loans and meeting with the members.

loans.use: Purchase fishing nets

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolanda C. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. She is 56 years old. Yolanda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells products such as snack foods, canned goods and instant noodles. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2011, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, such as canned goods and biscuits. This will be the first loan taken out by Yolanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, such as canned goods and biscuits

loans.name: Rizalina

texts.en: Rizalina is a 52-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a piggery. She lives in Victorias City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her piggery business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. Rizalina is borrowing PHP 21,000 to buy feed for her pigs. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rizalina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.en:
Virgilio L. is from the city of Guingona Ozamiz City. He is 46 years old. Virgilio is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Virgilio owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting gabi for sale. Virgilio has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Virgilio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgilio is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to pay for the labor cost for farm maintenance. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virgilio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay labor cost for farm maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell.

loans.name: Andrea Estefania

texts.es:
Lo de comerciante, Andrea Estefanía P. M. lo lleva en la sangre, pues su madre se ha dedicado a la venta de mercancía puerta a puerta, la falta de oportunidades laborales y de recursos económicos para continuar con sus estudios universitarios, impulsaron a esta joven de 20 años a iniciar con su propio negocio, una miscelanea en la ofrece diferentes productos. 

La violencia por la que atraviesa el sector de Itagui en el que Andrea tiene su negocio es una de las dificultades que esta joven emprendedora atraviesa, pues en algunas oportunidades esto limita sus ventas. Su perseverancia y ganas de salir adelante son los factores que la motivan a seguir luchando por su microempresa que en el futuro espera convertirse en una gran empresaria para generar empleo. 

Su negocio que apenas está empezando es la única fuente de ingresos de Andrea quien actualmente necesita de un préstamo para comprar más surtido y así ofrecer mayor variedad de productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Being a saleswoman is in Andrea Estefanía P. M.'s blood since her mother has spent her life selling merchandise door to door.  A lack of work opportunities and financial resources meant that Andrea could not complete her university studies.  Instead, they drove this 20 year-old woman to start her own business.  Andrea runs a general store where she sells a variety of products.  

The violence in Itagui sector, where Andrea has her business, is one of the difficulties that this young entrepreneur faces since, on some occasions, it has limited her sales.  However, her perseverance and desire to get ahead in life have motivated her to continue fighting for her small business.  In the future, she hopes to become an important businesswoman who creates employment.

Andrea's business, which she is just starting out in, is her only source of income.  She currently needs a loan to buy more stock so that she can offer a larger variety of products to her customers.

loans.use: to buy stock: accessories, lotions and beauty products

loans.name: Doris

texts.es: Doris es socia del Banco Comunal Estrella, casada con 28 años y tres hijos de 11, 10, 3 años de edad. Doris se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general, pollo, carne, verduras, frutas. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de arroz, azúcar, fideos, harina, verduras, frutas, para surtir su mercadería. Comenzó con éste negocio hace más de un año. Ingreso a FINCA Perú, por la invitación de una amiga, está en tres ciclos, le gusta por la facilidad de créditos y puede ahorrar, ahora está ahorrando para tener más capital de trabajo. Su sueño es que su negocio crezca, poder construir el tercer piso de su casa y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Doris is a member of the "Estrella" (Star) Communal Bank. She is married, 28 years old, and has three children ages 11, 10 and 3.

Doris sells groceries like chicken, beef, vegetables and fruit. The loan she is asking for will be used to buy rice, sugar, pasta, flour, vegetables and fruit to stock her store. She began this business more than a year ago.

Doris joined FINCA Perú because a friend invited her. She is in her third loan cycle, and she likes it because the loans are easy to deal with and she can save up money. Right now she is saving to have more working capital.

Her dream is that her business will grow, she will be able to build a third floor onto her house and her children will become professionals.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, pasta, flour, vegetables and fruit.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa is a producer of both palm oil and kernel oil at Abrafo, a village near Abura.  She has been through senior high school. She is married and has five dependents.
